content:
I've still got a few issues with this.
* the input format. And this is highly ironic, as my go-to gereral-purpose language can read those parenthesized int pairs in four characters or code. But this format does go against the general spirit here. As a hint, it shows in your stub generator: all you can provide in the default I/O code is "ROW", whereas your I/O section mentions CS And DS, nowhere to be seen in the stub.
* how to get from those CS/DS to the visual representation is probably obvious to those who still do HTML tables, but would really need a more strict definition of the layout flow: where a cs/ds pair in the input actually goes in the table. Especially with the variable spans.
* you call your operation "split", but it seems like it does more than that. Namely, it changes the table size. It could be called a split if it didn't have any influence elsewhere in the table, which would require it only being performed on cells with an even span in the requested direction. But as is seen in your example, it changes other cells' spans, so clarification is required.

Nits:
* "the table is rendered in HTML as"... no, it's the opposite, given HTML renders as a table.
* "The cell to be split never has a span in the direction asked" well, in the input specification each cell is given as a colspan/rowspan pair, neither of which is declared to be optional, so, yes, the cell to be split necessarily has a span in the split direction too. I get what you mean, but the current wording is flawed.

Pretty good puzzle, I'll approve it only if the input wasn't so messy to process in primitive languages like C++ that ignore the joys of split().
You could just as well put space-separated pairs of integers, that's about the most C++ can handle without writing tons of verbose code.
for instance:
(1,3) (2,1) -> 1 3 2 1

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

In the constraints :
"The cell to be split"
==> "The cell to be splitted"
Good puzzle.
This is a real world problem I just had in my job ;)  (just a bit easier version with a simplifying constraint)

uhm it seems to me that "split" is irregular...
am I wrong? (seems we both not native-english :) )

Eheh, let's think that I put it in this way for "simplify the parsing" with respect to HTML.
Tbh I put in that way input and output just to have it in the best human-readable form.
Maybe to merge our points of view, I can get rid of that parenthesis, but keep different separators between pair of coordinates, e.g.:
1,3 2,1
or:
1,3;2,1
or:
1 3,2 1
should this fulfill both of us?

Hi, answers:
* I cleaned up input/output removing parenthesis; for stub generator: I did not found a way to read a variable number of input from one row, aside putting a nested cycle that read, for each row, the number of cells following, but it seems to me even more confusing
* the title loudly announces that you need to know "HTML table" to afford this puzzle; since it is a global standard, you can found explanation everywhere much better than I can do in few lines...
* Got your point, modified description: it is just simple as thinking of drawing a line inside the given cell, and recalc all the spans
* Got your point, modified preposition
* Got your point ("no span"="span value one")
Thanks for your suggestions.

Stub: I appreciate the effort :-) But with no parentheses and still the comma, it's the worst of both worlds. Think of it this way: most C-derived languages (this might actually include Java in the CG style of thought) have proper parsing[*] for whitespace-delimited atoms. So if you can bring it to that perfect. It's possible in this puzzle by stripping all punctuation, that reduces it to a temperatures-style; it could be made even more parsable by turning each line in a sequence of [[NC]] number of new TDs, then NC lines of just [[CS]] [[RS]]. Unfortunately AFAIK the stub generator doesn't support nested loops, but you'd have a case to request CG staff help.
If you can't, or too seriously dislike the result for that, IMHO it was better with the parentheses. It's merely unfortunate that it makes your puzzle much more of a parsing one than necessary.

[*] yes I'm aware that *some* C-derived languages can handle comma separation. But CG is a multilanguage platform, puzzles have to strive for the common denominator.

HTML: I'm afraid this doesn't get a pass. Puzzles have to be self-contained; external links are tolerated for "culture", but not as a requirement to solve the puzzle. I could actually turn it against you: if you're not able to describe the HTML to table coordinates algorithm, are you sure *you* know HTML tables? From my memory of when I did HTML, it shouldn't need more than three sentences.

Splitting: Indeed, much better, thank you!

Nits: Great, thank you!

Getting rid of the parentheses sounds good to me. It should make the lines a bit easier for C++ while still being easy to process with split()-aware languages.

I've validated the puzzle anyway. Really fun to solve. Nice job!
You are perfectly right. To split, split, split. I made an horrific mistake. Shame on me.  :-)
